page_analysis.text_content:
Accessory structure daylight plane (sides & rear)

Fig 25 Front elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the side of the lot

Fig 26 Side elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the rear of the lot

Note: For accessory buildings near the rear & side lot lines, a hipped-gable roof is often the best solution for complying with the accessory-structure daylight plane.

32

visual_elements.description: Front elevation drawing showing an accessory structure with a dashed line representing the daylight plane at the side of the lot. The drawing includes vertical measurements: '8' from average grade' and '12' max. height of building'. The side lot lines are marked on both sides of the structure. The dashed line slopes upward from the side lot line at a ratio of 3:1 (horizontal to vertical).

Side elevation drawing showing an accessory structure with a dashed line representing the daylight plane at the rear of the lot. The drawing includes vertical measurements: '8' from average grade' and '12' max. height of building'. The rear lot line is marked. The dashed line slopes upward from the rear lot line at a ratio of 3:1 (horizontal to vertical).

A square diagram divided into four triangular sections with arrows indicating directions: 'Front' at the bottom left, 'Rear' at the bottom right, and 'Side' on the top and bottom sides. The arrows point outward from the center, illustrating orientation of the lot sides and rear.

technical_specifications.parameter: Minimum height from average grade to start of daylight plane
Maximum height of accessory structure building

additional_notes: Page number 32 at bottom left corner.
Note text emphasizes that a hipped-gable roof is often the best solution for accessory buildings near rear and side lot lines to comply with the daylight plane.
No handwritten annotations or stamps present.
All text and figures are clear and legible.

qualifiers.text: For accessory buildings near the rear & side lot lines, a hipped-gable roof is often the best solution for complying with the accessory-structure daylight plane.

conditions.text: Daylight plane starts 8' from average grade
Daylight plane slope ratio is 3:1 (horizontal to vertical)
